awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Intersections of worldviews in the co-management of environmental resources
awd_abstract_narration:
Millions of people worldwide are dependent on biodiverse marine habitats. These important habitats are subject to a variety of stresses and are thus experiencing severe degradation. How should they be managed? What frameworks are most effective in managing their use and in their conservation? This doctoral dissertation research examines the political dynamics of collaborative co-management of natural resources and the intersections of indigenous and other frameworks in driving management strategies. The research tests theories in cultural anthropology to understand how different relationships with the environment are expressed and resolved in dynamic ecological settings. It trains a doctoral dissertation student in theory and methods in scientific cultural anthropology and the work will be disseminated broadly to academic and non-academic audiences. 
 
This research pursues three objectives: 1) to compare understandings of human-environment relationality among indigenous and non-indigenous conservationists; 2) to examine how different understandings of relationality are incorporated into co-management policy and practice; and 3) to examine associated political dynamics. It uses ethnographic methods, including semi-structured interviews, participant observation, and social-ecological network analysis. The work develops a new analytical framework for incorporating different worldviews into the analysis of human-environment relationships. The work also contributes to our knowledge of how different perspectives and objectives are prioritized in co-management arrangements, ultimately informing the development of policy that engages local communities in sustainable resource management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Globally, millions of people are dependent on biodiverse marine habitats. These habitats are subject to a variety of stressors and are experiencing severe degradation. Collaborative conservation and management have become popular methods for managing such ecosystems so that they can continue to support human populations. However, the diverse perspectives and knowledges of collaborative conservation and management partners can lead to troubled partnerships that do not reach their full management potential. 

This research used ethnographic methods to examine the incorporation of diverse ideas into, and political dynamics of, collaborative conservation and management partnerships in New Caledonia, a French Overseas Territory in the South Pacific. The research examined how views of nature differed among different project participants as well as their motivations for participating in collaborative management and conservation projects. It also assessed how the perspectives, practices, and concerns, of the Indigenous Kanak, as partners on environmental management and conservation projects, could be better upheld within management frameworks. The main findings are as follows:

  • Indigenous Kanak individuals reported participating in conservation and management efforts as part of upholding their cultural and familial heritage. Whereas many non-Kanak individuals discussed the importance of protecting nature for its intrinsic values.
  • Conservationists of all backgrounds use awareness raising as a primary method for fostering more sustainable and environmentally friendly behaviors in their communities. Often awareness raising materials were shared between organizations, which could lead to knowledge hierarchies that privilege certain collaborative conservation partners knowledges over others, particularly scientific knowledges.
  • Analysis of five collaborative management plans from the North Province, New Caledonia showed that Indigenous-led management associations were charged with the greatest diversity of tasks, risking overburdening these communities who sometimes lack resources to carry out management activities.

This research contains lessons for how to craft collaborative conservation and management projects that equitably involve historically marginalized populations. It encourages those designing management and conservation projects to critically evaluate their plans for such projects, ensuring that all project partners are empowered rather than overburdened by project responsibilities. The research also demonstrates how certain types of knowledge in management arrangements come to be privileged via project partnerships. For collaborative conservation and management to work, multiple knowledge types should be equally considered as to bring together the diverse strengths of project partners for more effective and equitable conservation and management.
